channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Israel Agrees to Staggered Pauses in Fighting to Allow for Polio Vaccination, U.N. Says
item.description: Israel has emphasized the move is not the first step to a cease-fire, but that there would be limited pauses in specific areas to allow for the vaccinations.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Israel’s Hostage Rescue Highlights Challenge of Hamas Tunnels in Gaza
item.description: Gaza’s vast and complex subterranean network shelters many of Hamas’s remaining leaders, and is a key obstacle to eradicating the group.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier standing at the entrance to a tunnel inside a house in the central Gaza Strip in January, photographed as the Israeli military escorted international journalists into the area.

item.title: Battling Mpox in the Outbreak’s Epicenter
item.description: The New York Times visited a remote hospital in Congo where children and adults suffer with mpox, recently declared a global health emergency.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Lucy Letby Inquiry Won’t Weigh Key Question: Is the ‘Killer Nurse’ Innocent?
item.description: More than 20 experts have called on the U.K. government to delay a public inquiry into the case of Lucy Letby, who was convicted of murdering babies, because of growing concerns about the evidence.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: A video screen in Manchester, England, broadcasts the sentencing of Ms. Letby in 2023.

item.title: F-16 Fighter Jet, Recently Supplied to Ukraine, Crashes
item.description: A Western official said the advanced fighter crashed while defending against a Russian aerial assault. It was not clear how it was destroyed, but the loss is a blow to Ukraine, given the planes’ prominence.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: A F-16 during Ukraine’s Air Forces Day this month.

item.title: An Oil Tanker Is Stuck in the Red Sea After a Houthi Rebel Attack: What to Know
item.description: The MV Delta Sounion was carrying a million barrels of crude oil when it was attacked by Houthi rebels. On fire and crewless, it now poses an environmental risk.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: A photo released by the European Naval Mission in the Red Sea shows smoke rising from the MV Delta Sounion on Sunday.

item.title: Investigation Into Bayesian Yacht That Sank Off Sicily Broadens
item.description: Prosecutors are looking into the actions of two other crew members in connection with the sinking of the luxury yacht Bayesian, which caused the deaths of seven people.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Rescue personnel lift a body bag containing the corpse of British entrepreneur Mike Lynch, who died when a yacht owned by his family sank off the coast of Porticello, near the Sicilian city of Palermo, Italy, last week.

item.title: Top Biden Aide Holds Rare Talks With Chinese Military General
item.description: Jake Sullivan also met with China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, who said the United States should “find a correct way for the two major countries to get along.”
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and David Pierson
item.media:description: Jake Sullivan, the U.S. national security adviser, met with China’s leader, Xi Jinping, on Thursday.

item.title: 100-Plus Tons of Dead Fish Swamp a Greece Port
item.description: The mass deaths of the fish were most likely caused by climate change. The vacation area and its businesses have been suffering since.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: A bulldozer collecting dead fish in Volos, Greece. Authorities in central Greece said that they had dredged more than 100 tons of dead fish from the port city’s waters.

item.title: Ukraine Says It Struck 2 Russian Oil Depots
item.description: Kyiv is pressing its drone campaign while lobbying allies for permission to use weapons supplied by NATO countries for strikes deep inside Russia.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A satellite image released by Planet Labs on Wednesday showed smoke and flames rising from an oil depot in the Rostov region of Russia.

item.title: Push for Gender Equality in E.U.’s Top Roles Looks Set to Fall Short
item.description: Ursula von der Leyen, the European Commission president, asked member countries to nominate both men and women for commission roles.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, center, at the European Parliament with President Roberta Metsola in Strasbourg, France, in July. Ms. von der Leyen secured a second five-year term last month amid the ascent of harder-right political forces that made a strong showing in June’s E.U.-wide elections.

item.title: Sahra Wagenknecht Is Shaking Up German Politics From the East
item.description: Sahra Wagenknecht, a former Communist, has founded her own party to respond to German grievances about migrants, crime and the dangers of the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Sahra Wagenknecht at a campaign rally in Dresden, Germany, on Wednesday. She is considered, even by her opponents, to be a superb communicator and masterful at touching raw nerves in the population.

item.title: South Korean Court Orders Stronger Steps on Climate Change
item.description: A ruling by the Constitutional Court declared the nation’s current measures insufficient and a violation of the rights of future generations.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Climate activists cheering outside South Korea’s Constitutional Court in Seoul on Thursday. One-third of the complaints filed in the case came from children and teenagers.

item.title: Hong Kong Journalists Convicted of Sedition in Stand News Case
item.description: The editors said they published stories in the public interest. A judge ruled they were guilty of a crime against national security.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:description: Patrick Lam, left, and Chung Pui-kuen of Stand News leaving court in Hong Kong last year.

item.title: Inmate Revolts Highlight Failings and Miseries of Russian Prisons
item.description: Staff shortages, beatings, corruption and harsh treatment of Muslim prisoners have all led to unrest among inmates, with recent uprisings turning deadly.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Ekaterina Bodyagina
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Law enforcement officers approaching the IK-19 prison in the Volgograd region of Russia during a prisoner revolt there earlier this month.

item.title: How Mexico’s Judicial Overhaul Compares to Other Countries
item.description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s plan for transforming the judiciary goes much further than other countries that allow some judges to be elected.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Judiciary employees protest President Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s judicial overhaul at the Supreme Court of Justice this month in Mexico City.

item.title: Paris Is Utopia for Paralympians Until They Leave the Athletes’ Village
item.description: The city built highly accessible accommodations for competitors in the 2024 Paralympic Games. But the rest of Paris remains difficult to navigate.
item.dc:creator: Elena Bergeron and Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Accessible train stations are unusual in Paris, with only 25 percent of the rail system outfitted for people with disabilities.

item.title: Why Interest Rate Cuts Won’t Fix a Global Housing Affordability Crisis
item.description: Central bankers are lowering borrowing costs, but that won’t be a cure-all for a widespread lack of affordable housing.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Ash Adams for The New York Times
item.media:description: Moira Gallagher, pregnant with her third child, in her yard in Anchorage. She was edged out of the housing market in the neighborhood she grew up in, she said.

item.title: Parts of Italy’s Appian Way Are Left Off UNESCO’s World Heritage List. Cue Grievances.
item.description: For the towns along the ancient road that were not included on the UNESCO list, the slight is about more than hurt pride.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: The Arch of Drusus, on the Appian Way near Rome, this month.

item.title: Mining for Neutrinos and for Cosmic Answers
item.description: In a South Dakota cavern, scientists are working to capture the most elusive particles in the universe.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Howlett

item.title: Preaching the Mormon Gospel in Remotest Australia, With Art
item.description: In Northern Territory communities, missionaries rely on a special Indigenous edition of the Book of Mormon to get their message out.
item.dc:creator: Julia Bergin
item.category: Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)

item.title: Tropical Storm Shanshan Soaks Japan, Raising Flood and Landslide Risks
item.description: The weakened storm still packed heavy rain and strong winds. It has killed four people, injured over 100 and prompted evacuation orders for millions.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis, Kiuko Notoya and John Yoon
item.media:description: Floodwaters in Yufu, Japan, on Thursday.

item.title: Kiingi Tuheitia, King of the Maori in New Zealand, Dies at 69
item.description: The king, who had been on the throne for 18 years, was praised by New Zealand’s prime minister for his “unwavering commitment to his people.”
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:description: Kiingi Tuheitia in Huntly, New Zealand, in 2012.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Kamala Harris’s interview with CNN.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Israel Kills Militant Commander in West Bank Raid as Death Toll Reaches 17
item.description: The operation is the largest Israeli military incursion in over a year into the West Bank, which has become a third front in a conflict also being fought in Gaza and along the border with Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: A mosque damaged during an Israeli military operation in the northern West Bank, on Thursday.

item.title: What Is Palestinian Islamic Jihad?
item.description: The militant group was founded in Gaza in the 1980s, but remains far smaller and holds less sway than Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: A rally for Palestinian Islamic Jihad held in Gaza City in October 2022.

item.title: Namibia to Cull More Than 700 Wild Animals for Meat During Major Drought
item.description: The Southern African country plans to butcher over 700 wild animals, including 83 elephants and 300 zebras, to feed people and, it hopes, cut down on dangerous cross-species encounters.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: African elephants in the Huanib River Valley in northern Namibia in 2019. Namibia declared a state of emergency in May because of the devastating drought.

item.title: Climate-Friendly Meat? Regulators Tighten Scrutiny of Label Buzzwords.
item.description: The new guidelines from the Agriculture Department encourage third-party assessments of environment-related claims, which have come under fire.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: Companies have long had to get U.S.D.A. approval for food labels such as “cage free” eggs or “grass fed” beef.

item.title: Friday Briefing: A Defining Harris Interview
item.description: Plus, a picnic battle on Italy’s beaches.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta and Justin Porter
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris being interviewed on CNN in June.

item.title: Honduras Says It Will End Extradition Treaty With U.S. After Ambassador Remarks
item.description: Honduran leaders, angered after remarks by the U.S. ambassador, said they would terminate the century-old extradition treaty, which was recently used to extradite a former president.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner and Joan Suazo
item.media:description: President Xiomara Castro of Honduras, shown speaking at the United Nations last year. This week, she said the United States’ “intention to direct the politics of Honduras through its embassy and other representatives is intolerable.”

item.title: Telegram Founder Pavel Durov’s Indictment Thrusts Encryption Into the Spotlight
item.description: The criminal charges against Pavel Durov, Telegram’s founder, raised concerns in Silicon Valley about encryption and the app’s approach to privacy and security.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:description: Pavel Durov’s lawyer, David-Olivier Kaminski, leaving court in Paris on Wednesday. Telegram, Mr. Durov’s messaging service, tackles encryption differently than WhatsApp, Signal and others.

item.title: Weaver Bird Nests in Africa Appear to Reflect Local Styles and Traditions
item.description: Sparrow weavers in Africa appear to learn distinct building styles that reflect group traditions, research shows. It raises intriguing questions about avian intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Dzombak
item.media:description: A white-browed sparrow weaver in Maasai Mara National Reserve, Kenya. Nest building was long thought to be purely innate behavior.

item.title: Inside U.S. Efforts to Avert War Among Iran, Israel and Hezbollah
item.description: A bigger disaster may have been avoided, even as the region continues to teeter on the brink of wider war.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley, Eric Schmitt and Edward Wong
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and other U.S. officials have worked almost nonstop in the past month to contain the latest tit-for-tat cycle of violence in the Middle East.

item.title: No Vaccines, Tests or Treatments: Congo Lacks Tools to Confront Mpox
item.description: The country at the center of a global health emergency is struggling even to diagnose cases and provide basic care.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:credit: Arlette Bashizi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Benedi Manegabe, 21, discussing his mpox progression with a nurse at a hospital in Kavumu, South Kivu Province, in the Democratic Republic of Congo on Saturday.

item.title: Son of Spanish Actor Is Convicted of Murdering and Dismembering Surgeon in Thailand
item.description: Daniel Sancho Bronchalo was sentenced to life imprisonment after a court in Koh Samui ruled that he was guilty of murdering Edwin Arrieta Arteaga last year.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Mr. Sancho being escorted by a police officer on Koh Phangan, an island known for its full-moon parties.

item.title: UN World Food Program Halts Gaza Aid Deliveries After Team Hit by Gunfire
item.description: The U.N. agency said that none of its employees were harmed in the shooting, which occurred Tuesday night near an Israeli military checkpoint.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: World Food Program, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo made available by the World Food Program on Thursday shows a W.F.P. car that came under fire a few yards from an Israeli checkpoint at the Wadi Gaza bridge.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Pavel Durov in 2014.

item.title: Tropical Storm Shanshan Drenches Southern Japan, Disrupting Train and Air Travel
item.description: The storm weakened after making landfall as a typhoon, still posed the risk of landslides and floods as it moved at a crawling speed.
item.dc:creator: Hisako Ueno, Yan Zhuang and John Yoon
item.media:description: High waves along the shores of southwestern Japan on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Blames Biden for Wars Abroad. Here’s a Look at Their Records.
item.description: Former President Donald J. Trump blames President Biden for crises around the globe. But the reality is that presidents inherit a world already hurtling through history.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump believes the world would be a very different place if he had not lost the 2020 election.

item.title: Algerian Man Charged Over Synagogue Arson Attack in France
item.description: The man expressed deep hatred of Jews and said he had acted to “support the Palestinian cause,” according to French antiterrorism prosecutors.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: A damaged car in a parking garage outside the Beth-Yaacov synagogue in La Grande-Motte, southern France.

item.title: What Is the West Bank and Who Controls It?
item.description: Renewed violence has cast a spotlight on the territory, where more than 600 Palestinians have been killed in clashes with the Israeli military since Oct. 7.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Afif Amireh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Surveying the damage after clashes in Jenin, in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, in December.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Israel Launches Major West Bank Raids
item.description: Plus, charges for Telegram’s founder.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta and Justin Porter
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers near Tulkarm in the West Bank, yesterday.

item.title: Israeli Military Begins Major West Bank Raids
item.description: Hundreds of troops entered cities in the occupied territory, targeting Palestinian militants. It was a significant escalation after months of raids that have unfolded alongside the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Adam Rasgon, Raja Abdulrahim and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers operate during a raid near Tulkarm, in the occupied West Bank, on Wednesday.

item.title: Family of Bedouin Hostage Celebrates His Release and Prays for Cease-Fire
item.description: The marginalized Bedouin community suffered deaths and abductions during the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attack, and also ache for their Palestinian relatives in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Rawan Sheikh Ahmad and Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Farhan al-Qadi in Karkur, Israel, on Wednesday. He said he had lost around 28 pounds because he was too distraught during 10 months of captivity, most spent in underground tunnels.

item.title: A 4-Year-Old Boy Breaks a 3,500-Year-Old Jar at an Israeli Museum
item.description: The child, who had been visiting the Hecht Museum in Haifa, wanted to know what was in the jar, his father said. He and his family have been invited to return when the artifact is restored.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:description: The ancient jar that was accidentally smashed into pieces by a 4-year-old boy during a trip to the Hecht Museum, in Haifa, Israel.

item.title: C.I.A. Warning Helped Thwart ISIS Attack at Taylor Swift Concert in Vienna
item.description: The agency provided information about several suspects that led to arrests, the deputy director said.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Taylor Swift had been planning to hold three concerts in Vienna beginning Aug. 8, and 200,000 people had been expected to attend.

item.title: Keir Starmer Hopes to ‘Turn a Corner on Brexit’ and Reset Ties With E.U.
item.description: On a trip to Germany, Prime Minister Keir Starmer exchanged warm words with Germany’s chancellor, Olaf Scholz. But a reset with the European Union will depend on actions too.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, left, with Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain on Wednesday in Berlin.

item.title: U.S. and Chinese Officials Discuss Future Talks Between Biden and Xi
item.description: In discussions in Beijing, the two sides made clear that many differences remain over Taiwan, technology export controls and trade disputes.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and David Pierson
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Ng Han Guan
item.media:description: Jake Sullivan, President Biden’s national security adviser, and Wang Yi, China’s top foreign policy official, in Beijing on Wednesday.

item.title: Major Israeli-Palestinian Clashes in the West Bank: A Timeline
item.description: Israel has ramped up a crackdown in the Israeli-occupied territory since before the Israel-Hamas war began last Oct. 7. Here are some of the major raids.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Surveying damage after an Israeli military raid in the West Bank city of Jenin in November.

item.title: Jenin, a Target of Israeli Raids, Is a Symbol of Palestinian Restiveness
item.description: For decades, Jenin has played a central role in fighting against occupying powers.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: A woman raised a Palestinian flag in the ruins of Jenin in 2002, after much of the area was destroyed in a two-week Israeli military offensive.

item.title: Shelling Kills 6 in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: The rest of the country, though, was largely spared from another consecutive night of large-scale Russian bombardment.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kryvyi Rih, Ukraine, after a strike on Wednesday.

item.title: Last Crusade of Mexico’s President: A Drastic Redesign of the Judiciary
item.description: A showdown over plans to reshape the entire judiciary is raising fears over the effect on the rule of law in Mexico and trade with the United States.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Paulina Villegas
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador, who has enjoyed historically high approval ratings, surrounded by a crowd of supporters during a rally in 2022 in Mexico City.

item.title: Germany’s State Elections Are Likely to Reveal a Still-Divided Country
item.description: Closely watched elections in the former East Germany are likely to reveal a still-divided country and yield a worrying challenge to Berlin.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: The city center of Erfurt, in the German state of Thuringia. It is one of three states in the former East Germany facing critical elections in September.

item.title: Typhoon Shanshan Barrels Into Japan, Triggering Rare Warnings
item.description: The authorities said the storm could produce a large-scale disaster as it approached the mainland. Nearly 1 million people were told to evacuate, and Toyota closed all its factories on Wednesday afternoon.
item.dc:creator: Hisako Ueno and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: High waves along the shores of southwestern Japan on Wednesday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Jack Smith, the special counsel.

item.title: In Quebec’s Casse-Croûtes, Fast Food for a Short but Sweet Summer
item.description: By now, the most famous product of Quebec’s casse-croûtes, the poutine, has gone international. But can the guédille or the pinso ever become just as popular?
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Nasuna Stuart-Ulin
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Customers consulting the extensive menu as they wait in line to order a nighttime treat from Casse-Croûte La Mollière in Cap-des-Rosiers, Gaspé, Quebec.

item.title: Why Hasn’t Russia Kicked Out Ukrainian Invaders? Its Own Invaders Are Busy.
item.description: Despite its overwhelming firepower, Russia has been unable for weeks to push Ukrainian troops back across the border, with the failure as much the result of priorities as a lack of personnel.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman about to board an evacuation train in Pokrovsk, Ukraine, on Tuesday. The advance on the city by Russian forces has not been slowed by the Kursk incursion.

item.title: With Hezbollah-Israel Conflict Contained, Iran’s Next Move May Be Modest
item.description: After weeks of regional fears about a broader war, Hezbollah’s limited attack on Israel suggests that Iran, like its ally, wants to hem in the risk of escalation.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah fighters carrying the coffin of Fuad Shukr, a senior commander who was killed in an Israeli airstrike on July 30.

item.title: Africa’s Debt Crisis Has ‘Catastrophic Implications’ for the World
item.description: Crushing obligations to foreign creditors that have few precedents have sapped numerous African nations of growth and stoked social instability.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Brian Otieno for The New York Times
item.media:description: Proposed tax increases resulted in deadly protests in Kenya this summer.
